message.content:
A Charadrius tricollaris, also known as the three-banded plover, is a small bird species belonging to the family Charadriidae.
It measures about 16-18 cm in length and has a characteristic white forehead, black cheek patch, and three distinct black bands on its chest.
The upperparts are brown, wings are black with a white wingbar, and the underparts are white.
The bill is short and black, while the legs are a yellowish-orange color.
This bird species is mainly found in coastal areas, such as beaches, estuaries, and mudflats.
It feeds on invertebrates, such as crustaceans, insects, and worms.
The Charadrius tricollaris is considered a particularly vulnerable species due to habitat loss and disturbance by human activities.
